docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Rep. Rob Andrews announced Tuesday that he is resigning from Congress after more than 23 years, a decision that could short-circuit a House Ethics Committee inquiry into whether the New Jersey Democrat used campaign donations for personal purposes.

headline.print_headline: US Rep. Rob Andrews of NJ Resigning After 23 Years

docs.lead_paragraph: The Congressional Budget Office on Tuesday reduced its estimate of the U.S. budget deficit for the current fiscal year but said sluggish economic growth and stubbornly high unemployment will cause the improvement to be short-lived.

headline.main: U.S. Deficit to Decline, Then Rise as Labor Market Struggles: CBO
headline.print_headline: U.S. Deficit to Decline, Then Rise as Labor Market Struggles: CBO

docs.snippet: The Congressional Budget Office on Tuesday reduced its estimate of the U.S. budget deficit for the current fiscal year but said sluggish economic growth and stubbornly high unemployment will cause the improvement to be short-lived.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican governors and lawmakers who now control a majority of state capitols have been pushing aggressively to cut spending and shrink government — with one glaring exception.

headline.main: A New Entitlement? The Right to Preschool
headline.print_headline: A New Entitlement? The Right to Preschool

docs.lead_paragraph: The looming negotiations with the city’s unions over new contracts will give Mayor Bill de Blasio the chance to be a tougher kind of progressive.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds that looming negotiations over New York City's union contracts will give Mayor Bill de Blasio, presenting his first budget, the chance to be a tougher kind of progressive; holds de Blasio will have to demand concession from his union allies if he is going to have the funds to pursue his ambitious liberal agenda.
docs.snippet: The looming negotiations with the city’s unions over new contracts will give Mayor Bill de Blasio the chance to be a tougher kind of progressive.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly three months after a ruinous typhoon, Tacloban, once a thriving center, shows few signs of recovery, and those who can are leaving to find jobs elsewhere.

headline.main: Months After Typhoon, Philippine City Suffers From an Exodus of Jobs
headline.print_headline: Months After Typhoon, Philippine City Suffers From an Exodus of Jobs

docs.abstract: Once-thriving Philippine city of Tacloban shows relatively few signs of economic recovery nearly three months after Typhoon Haiyan ravaged the area, despite an international rescue effort; many residents who are able to leave are looking for jobs in other parts of the country.
docs.snippet: Nearly three months after a ruinous typhoon, Tacloban, once a thriving center, shows few signs of recovery, and those who can are leaving to find jobs elsewhere.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Monday said it will soon begin hearings to resolve problems for people who enrolled in health insurance through the Obamacare website HealthCare.gov, only to encounter errors including unnecessarily high costs.

headline.main: U.S. Says HealthCare.gov Enrollment Appeal Hearings to Begin Soon
headline.print_headline: U.S. Says HealthCare.gov Enrollment Appeal Hearings to Begin Soon

docs.snippet: The Obama administration on Monday said it will soon begin hearings to resolve problems for people who enrolled in health insurance through the Obamacare website HealthCare.gov, only to encounter errors including unnecessarily high costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: “Our health care system is broken,” says Barry Werth. In his new book, “The Antidote,” he provides an inside look at one company’s efforts to find innovative ways to treat disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: A research center funded by the Affordable Care Act is being criticized for not using proven methods like clinical trials to learn how to best deliver care.

headline.main: Method of Study Is Criticized in Group’s Health Policy Tests
headline.print_headline: Method of Study Is Criticized in Group’s Health Policy Tests

docs.abstract: Innovation Center, research facility funded by Affordable Care Act, is being criticized by many researchers and economists for not using proven methods like randomized clinical trials to learn how to best deliver health care; experts say center, which undertakes mostly demonstration projects, is squandering crucial opportunity to develop evidence needed to retool nation's troubled health care system.
docs.snippet: A research center funded by the Affordable Care Act is being criticized for not using proven methods like clinical trials to learn how to best deliver care.
